Scenes from Fenway's 100th

The Sox celebrated the 100th anniversary of the first game at Fenway Park in 1912 by bringing 213 players out onto the field to take their positions. Aram Boghosian/Globe Photo
The Red Sox invited their alumni to return for the Fenway 100 celebration, and about 200 showed up for the pregame festivities. John Tlumacki/Globe Staff
Former Red Sox players Kevin Millar and Pedro Martinez raised a toast with all the fans to celebrate 100 years of Fenway Park. John Tlumacki/Globe Staff
Fans raised their glasses before the game between the Yankees and the Red Sox this afternoon. Elsa/Getty Images
Former Red Sox manager Terry Francona, who led the team to World Series championships in 2004 and 2007, waved to the crowd. John Tlumacki/Globe Staff
Hall of Famer and former Red Sox catcher Carlton Fisk acknowledged the cheers from the crowd at Fenway. John Tlumacki/Globe Staff
After the anniversary ceremonies, the Red Sox took the field for the start of the game John Tlumacki/Globe Staff
Caroline Kennedy threw out the first pitch as Sox owner John Henry looked on before the start of the game. John Tlumacki/Globe Staff
John Williams conducted The Boston Pops in a rendition of "Fanfare for Fenway" and the national anthem behind home plate. John Tlumacki/Globe Staff
A fighter jet and a vintage aircraft flew side-by-side over Fenway Park as part of the conclusion to the afternoon celebration. John Tlumacki/Globe Staff

Bill Brett's party photos from Fenway Park

The Red Sox held a luncheon at the Fenway today. At left, Linda Pizzuti Henry, wife of Red Sox owner John Henry, and musician Peter Wolf.

New Zealand woman's Coca-Cola drinking habit cited in her death

Experts say a New Zealand woman's 2-gallon-a-day Coca-Cola habit probably contributed to her death. The soft-drink giant responded that even water can be deadly in excess.
